title: Food Poisoning (Foodborne Illness)
body:
Food poisoning is a foodborne illness caused by eating or drinking contaminated items; symptoms typically start within hours or days (sometimes weeks) and may involve the gut or, less commonly, the nervous system.

**Symptoms**
- Upset stomach, vomiting, loose or bloody stools, stomach pain or cramps, fever
- Less common neurologic signs: blurred or double vision, headaches, paralysis, tingling, numbness, weakness
- Potential complications include severe dehydration, bloodstream infections, kidney failure, chronic arthritis, irritable bowel syndrome, Guillain-Barré syndrome and breathing problems such as botulism

**Causes**
- Contaminants include bacteria, viruses, intestinal parasites, toxins, toxin-producing bacteria and toxin-producing molds
- Foodborne illness covers any contaminated food or drink; food poisoning is the subset caused by toxins in food
- Food can be tainted during growing, harvesting, processing, storing, shipping or preparation through poor handwashing, dirty utensils/surfaces or improper storage temperatures (e.g., food left at room temperature too long)

**Prevention**
- Cleaning: wash hands with soap and water for 20 seconds, rinse fruits/vegetables, clean utensils with hot soapy water after raw foods, and clean refrigerators regularly (baking-soda solution; bleach for mold)
- Preparing/eating/storing: keep raw foods separate, thaw/cook/store foods safely, cook meats to safe temperatures, refrigerate or freeze leftovers promptly, discard questionable or moldy foods (trim mold only from firm, low-moisture foods when appropriate)
- High-risk groups (pregnant people, young children, older adults, immunocompromised): avoid raw or undercooked meats, fish, shellfish, eggs or foods containing raw eggs, raw sprouts, unpasteurized juices/milk, soft or unpasteurized cheeses, refrigerated pâtés/meat spreads and uncooked deli meats unless reheated

**When to See a Doctor**
- Infants and children: seek medical care for vomiting and loose stools plus behavior changes, extreme thirst, little or no urine, dizziness, diarrhea lasting more than a day, frequent vomiting, blood or pus in stools, severe abdominal or rectal pain, any fever in children under 2, fever ≥102°F (38.9°C) in older children or when other medical problems exist
- Adults: seek care for nervous-system symptoms (blurry vision, muscle weakness, skin tingling), mental changes, temperature ≥103°F (39.4°C), frequent vomiting, diarrhea lasting more than three days, or dehydration signs such as intense thirst, dry mouth, little/no urination, weakness, dizziness and lightheadedness
